Description: Cargill, Inc., a Delaware corporation, has reached an administrative civil settlement with EPA over alleged violations of the Clean Air Act at its Vitamin E manufacturing facility in Eddyville, Iowa.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epa/newsreleases/cargill-inc-agrees-settle-clean-air-act-violations-vitamin-e-manufacturing-facility.html

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced the resolution of a series of settlements under the Clean Water Act with Safety-Kleen Systems, Inc., in Newark, Calif., and Cargill Corporation, in Fullerton, Calif., for violations of federal oil pollution prevention regulations. Safety-Kleen will pay a $90,000 penalty and Cargill will pay a $45,000 penalty to resolve the violations at their facilities.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epa/newsreleases/us-epa-requires-california-companies-improve-oil-spill-prevention-plans.html

Description: As part of a Clean Air Act settlement, Cargill agreed to spend an estimated $130 million to install air pollution control devices at its 27 corn and oilseed processing facilities, pay a civil penalty of $1.6 million and spend $3.5 million on environmental projects across the country.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2005/September/05_enrd_448.html

Description: Cargill Incorporated, a privately held multinational corporation headquartered in Minnetonka, Minn., has agreed to settle allegations that it violated the Clean Water Act (CWA) at two different large oil storage facilities located in Blair, Neb., and Eddyville, Iowa.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/0a9ea6113bb7868185257d31006b482f.html

Agency: Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau
Info Source: https://www.ttb.gov/images/pdfs/fo-compromise/2011/cargill.pdf
https://www.fra.dot.gov/eLib/details/L16190#p1_z5_gD_lEA

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Info Source: https://www.fra.dot.gov/eLib/details/L17311#p1_z5_gD_lEA

Description: Cargill Meat Solutions agreed to settle allegations of hiring discrimination based on race and sex by paying $2,236,218 in back wages and interest to 2,959 applicants who were rejected for production jobs at facilities in Springdale, Ark.; Fort Morgan, Colo.; and Beardstown, Ill., between 2005 and 2009.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/ofccp/ofccp20140010

Description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the filing and simultaneous settlement of charges against Cargill, Inc. for providing mid-market marks that concealed from counterparties and its swap data repository (SDR) its full mark-up on certain swaps, in violation of the Commodity Exchange Act and Commission Regulations.
Info Source: http://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/pr7640-17

Description: Cargill Pork Inc., which operated a 17,000 pig farming operation in Martinsburg, Mo., pleaded guilty to violating the Clean Water Act and agreed to pay a total of $1,551,000, including a fine of $1 million, $51,000 in restitution to the State of Missouri for natural resources damages and the costs of investigation and $500,000 in already spent remediation costs.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://yosemite.epa.gov/opa/admpress.nsf/b1ab9f485b098972852562e7004dc686/4dc49cd1c44b8a6c85256b6e006f01f5?OpenDocument
https://www.fra.dot.gov/Elib/Document/17839

Private Litigation Case Title: Barbosa v. Cargill Meat Solutions Corp.
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/401210/cargill-meat-to-pay-1-3m-in-ot-class-action-deal

Private Litigation Case Title: Shackleford et al v. Cargill Meat Solutions Corporation
Salcido et al v. Cargill Meat Solutions Corp., et al
In Re Cargill Meat Solutions Corp. Wage and Hour Litigation

Description: The court reduced a jury verdict for punitive damage from $1 million to $235,000 and awarded $102,043 in legal fees.
Private Litigation Case Title: Leal v. Cargill, Inc., et al
Info Source: 2002 Jury Verdicts LEXIS 56776
https://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/release/9-14-18.cfm

Description: Cargill agreed to pay $3.5 million on environmental projects as part of the settlement of multistate litigation alleging violations of the Clean Air Act. This was part of a larger $135 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-cargill-inc-1
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2005/September/05_enrd_448.html

Description: Cargill agreed to pay $286,778 in settlement of allegations it violated the Missouri Clean Water Law when its McCraw Farm discharged hog waste into the Loutre River, killing thousands of fish.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20030307013233/http://www.ago.state.mo.us/newsrls/2002/092502b.htm

Description: The Ohio Attorney General announced an $11.5 million settlement with Morton Salt Inc. and Cargill Inc. to resolve allegations that the companies conspired with each other, causing state and local governments to pay higher prices on the rock salt used to make icy roads safer for travelers.
Info Source: https://www.ohioattorneygeneral.gov/Media/News-Releases/June-2015/Ohio-Attorney-General-DeWine-Announces-$11-5-Milli

Description: Excel Corp. agreed to pay $125,000 in settlement of allegations it violated the parameters of its permit to treat and dispose of wastewater generated at its Beardstown facility.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20010307224107/http://www.ag.state.il.us/pressrelease/082200.htm

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/ofccp/foia/files/2019-09-26Cargill-CA-SW-NO-version_Redacted.pdf

Description: Six poultry companies agreed to pay a total of $7.5 million to the City of Tulsa to resolve a lawsuit concerning water pollution. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.
Info Source: Arkansas poultry firms, Tulsa settle lawsuit over water, Associated Press, July 16, 2003 (via Nexis).

Company: Cargill, Inc. and Salt City, Inc.
Info Source: https://www.mass.gov/news/ags-office-reaches-settlements-with-companies-that-illegally-discharged-polluted-stormwater

Description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an order simultaneously filing and settling charges against Cargill Inc., a provisionally registered swap dealer doing business through its Cargill Risk Management business unit, for failing to comply with its reporting obligations as a swap dealer and failing to supervise its reporting obligations adequately. The order requires Cargill to pay a $750,000 civil monetary penalty and to cease and desist from any further violations of the Commodity Exchange Act or CFTC regulations, as charged.
Info Source: https://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/8442-21
